questions.question: Is the messenger RNA not a vaccine but an operate arrangement that controls the cells ?

answers.answer: messenger RNA vaccines are a new engineering being used for preventing COVID-19 contagion . One of the vaccines s the Comirnaty COVID-19 messenger RNA vaccine ( also known as the ‘ Pfizer-BioNTech messenger RNA vaccine ’ ) . What is mRNA ? Ribonucleic acerb ( RNA ) is the genetic fabric in viruses such as SARS-CoV-2 ( the COVID-19 virus ) . Once inside a human cellular telephone , SARS-CoV-2 RNA acts as messenger ribonucleic acerb ( messenger RNA ) , which is a character of atom used by the virus as instructions for making the proteins it needs to affair . Human cells generate messenger RNA for the same function . How do mRNA vaccines work ? Vaccines prepare the torso to defend itself against a specific disease . messenger RNA vaccines contain pieces of messenger RNA that tell the cells in the torso how to make a viral protein that will be recognised by the immune arrangement as foreign . In this event , the messenger RNA contains instructions for the ear ( S ) protein on the open of the SARS-CoV-2 virus . The S protein helps the virus enroll human cells . Copies of the S protein are made in the torso . The immune arrangement recognises the S protein copies as foreign and makes immune cells and antibodies which can recognise and attack the SARS-CoV-2 virus via the S protein . The messenger RNA is broken down shortly after inoculation . Animal studies showed that the messenger RNA in the Comirnaty vaccine is broken down within a match of weeks . If the torso is later exposed to the SARS-CoV-2 virus , the immune arrangement is prepared to defend the torso against illness . As a consequence some people may not get infected at all . Others will experience a much milder illness than they would have done without the vaccine .

Vaccines traditionally contain either weakened viruses or purified touch proteins of the virus . But an mRNA vaccine is different , because rather than having the viral protein injected , a person receives genetic fabric – messenger RNA – that encodes the viral protein . When these genetic instructions are injected into the upper weapon , the muscleman cells translate them to make the viral protein directly in the torso . This access mimics what the SARS-CoV-2 does in nature – but the vaccine messenger RNA codes only for the critical shard of the viral protein . This gives the immune arrangement a preview of what the real virus looks like without causing disease . This preview gives the immune arrangement clock time to design powerful antibodies that can neutralize the real virus if the person is ever infected . While this synthetic messenger RNA is genetic fabric , it can not be transmitted to the next coevals . After an messenger RNA injection , this atom guides the protein product inside the muscleman cells , which reaches extremum levels for 24 to 48 hours and can last for a few more days .

answers.answer: Theodore Roosevelt is the only U.S. President of the United States to have received the Medal of Honor , which he was awarded posthumously . When the Spanish-American War broke out , Assistant Secretary of the Navy Theodore Roosevelt famously quit his occupation to lead a volunteer regiment known as the Rough Riders . Roosevelt and his men played a decisive function in the Battle of San Juan Hill and took region in other confrontations in Cuba . In 1916 , less than three years before his end , the 26th President of the United States was nominated for the Medal of Honor , but the Army passed him over , citing a miss of attest for his heroic verse actions at San Juan Hill . President Bill Clinton posthumously awarded him the decoration in 2001 . Roosevelt ’ s son , Theodore Jr. , who served in both World Wars , also received the Medal of Honor .

questions.question: What did the survey reason ?

answers.answer: Conclusions.We did not detect SARS-CoV-2 RNA in milk produced by women with mild-to-moderate COVID-19 . Moreover , we demonstrated that milk contains anti-SARS-CoV-2 antibodies and that their concentrations are correlated with milk ’ s ability to effectively neutralize SARS-CoV-2 infectivity . We found attest of SARS-CoV-2 on the areola/nipple area of several women , but it is unclear whether this RNA reflects viable virus . As such , our data do not suggest that infected women should systematically wash their breasts prior to breastfeeding or expressing milk . However , and in documentation of recommendations put forth by the WHO , if a beget who is confirmed/suspected to have COVID-19 has just coughed over her exposed summit , she should gently wash the summit with soap and warm body of water before eating ( 37 ) . Taken together with the well-documented benefits of breastfeeding to maternal and infant health , our data documentation recommendations to encourage breastfeed in women with mild-to-moderate COVID-19 illness .

questions.question: What does the WHO say about Covid-9 and breast milk ?

answers.answer: Breastmilk is the best beginning of nutriment for infants , including infants whose mothers have confirmed or suspected coronavirus contagion . As long as an infected beget takes appropriate precautions—outlined below—she can breastfeed her child . Breastmilk contains antibodies and other immunological benefits that can help protect against respiratory diseases . A growing torso of attest supports the importance of breastfeeding for a child ’ s increase , growth , and health , as well as for helping them avoid fleshiness and noncommunicable diseases later in animation . What is the hazard forbreastfed infants ? To go steady , the virus that causes COVID-19 has not been detected in breastmilk.However , as the disease is new , this attest is based on limited studies . Public health officials are continuing to learn about how the virus spreads and what kind of risks it poses to infants whose mothers have the disease . In limited studies among women with COVID-19 and another coronavirus contagion ( Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome , SARs-CoV ) , the virus was not detected in breastmilk . In a recent survey from Wuhan , China , researchers collected and tested breastmilk samples ( at first suckling ) from six patients who had COVID-19 during pregnancy ; all samples tested negative for the virus . However , more inquiry is needed to confirm these results . Of importance , the know obtained so far shows that the disease path of COVID-19 generally is not severe in infants and young children . The main hazard of transmittance appears to come from the respiratory nerve pathway of an infected beget .

questions.question: What are the disclaimers added to the covid 19 vaccine chemical reaction report card

answers.answer: VAERS accepts reports of adverse events and reactions that occur following inoculation . Healthcare providers , vaccine manufacturers , and the populace can submit reports to VAERS . The reports may contain data that is incomplete , inaccurate , coincidental , or unverifiable . Most reports to VAERS are voluntary , which means they are subject to biases . This creates specific limitations on how the data can be used scientifically . Data from VAERS reports should always be interpreted with these limitations in judgment .

questions.question: Is there discriminatory USDA policies leading to land personnel casualty among Black farmers ?

answers.boolean_explanation: A 1965 report card from the U.S. Commission on Civil Rights found that Black farmers received inferior discussion from USDA agencies compared with white farmers . In the South , where most Black farmers operated , federally assisted state of matter propagation services were `` administered through a separate social organization and generally on a discriminatory footing , '' the report card said . It said that a large share of white farmers in the South , aided by federal loans and technical advice , diversified their crops and applied modern farm practices . That helped them raise their incomes , expand their farms , improve their caparison and advance their Department of Education . But about a one-fourth of a million Black farmers `` stand as a glaring exception to this painting of advancement . '' Among the issues raised in the report card : Black farmers got smaller loans and far less steering than white farmers in the same economic course . White borrowers got most of their loans for Das Kapital investments , such as grow improvements or expansion , while Black farmers ’ loans were primarily for life expenses and annual operate costs .

answers.answer: Yes

questions.question: What is mRNA ?

answers.answer: Messenger RNA Carries the Instructions for Making Proteins messenger RNA is “ messenger ” RNA . messenger RNA is synthesized in the core using the nucleotide succession of DNA as a template . This procedure requires nucleotide triphosphates as substrates and is catalyzed by the enzyme RNA polymerase II . The procedure of making messenger RNA from deoxyribonucleic acid is called arrangement , and it occurs in the core . The messenger RNA directs the deduction of proteins , which occurs in the cytoplasm . messenger RNA formed in the core is transported out of the core and into the cytoplasm where it attaches to the ribosomes . Proteins are assembled on the ribosomes using the messenger RNA nucleotide succession as a usher . Thus mRNA carries a “ message ” from the core to the cytoplasm . The message is encoded in the nucleotide succession of the messenger RNA , which is complementary to the nucleotide succession of the deoxyribonucleic acid that served as a template for synthesizing the messenger RNA . Making proteins from messenger RNA is called transformation .

In the natural universe , the torso relies on millions of tiny proteins to keep itself alive and healthy , and it uses mRNA to tell cells which proteins to make . If you could design your own messenger RNA , you could , in hypothesis , commandeer that procedure and create any protein you might desire — antibodies to vaccinate against contagion , enzymes to reverse a rare disease , or increase agents to mend damaged center weave .

It is thought to be able to cure many genetic disorders or treat them over clock time .

answers.answer: The exercise of impeachment originated in England and was later used by many of the American colonial and state of matter governments . As adopted by the framers of the Constitution , this congressional ability is a fundamental part of the arrangement of “ checks and balances. ” Through the impeachment procedure , Congress charges and then tries an official of the federal politics for “ Treason , Bribery , or other high Crimes and Misdemeanors. ” The definition of “ high Crimes and Misdemeanors ” was not specified in the Constitution and has long been the discipline of argument . In impeachment proceedings , the House of Representatives charges an official of the federal politics by approving , by simple majority right to vote , articles of impeachment . After the House of Representatives sends its articles of impeachment to the Senate , the Senate sits as a High Court of Impeachment to consider attest , hear witnesses , and right to vote to acquit or convict the impeached official . A committee of representatives , called “ managers , ” work as prosecutors before the Senate . In the event of presidential impeachment trials , the chief judge of the United States presides .

questions.question: What caused the current COVID-19 pandemic ?

answers.answer: The current COVID-19 pandemic is caused by a coronavirus named SARS-CoV-2 . Coronaviruses ( CoVs ) are a large class of viruses , several of which campaign respiratory diseases in humans , from the common coldness to more rare and serious diseases such as the Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome ( SARS ) and the Middle East respiratory syndrome ( MERS ) , both of which have high deathrate rates and were detected for the first clock time in 2003 and 2012 , respectively . CoVs are divided into four genus : alpha- , beta- , gamma- and delta-CoV . All CoVs currently known to cause disease in humans belong to the alpha- or the beta-CoV . Many of these CoVs can infect several animal species as well . SARS-CoV infected civet cats and infected humans in 2002 and MERS-CoV is found in dromedary camels and infected humans in 2012 . A virus that is regularly transmitted from an animal to a homo is called a zoonotic virus . When a virus passes from animals to humans for the first clock time it is called a spillover consequence

questions.question: Was Donald Trump impeached for his NFL criticism ?

answers.answer: Trump was impeached on two articles . The first right to vote , 230-197 , accused him of maltreatment of ability and was almost entirely on party lines ; it was followed quickly by a second , 229-198 , right to vote accusing the President of the United States of obstructing Congress . The one-vote deviation was that of Democrat Jared Golden of Maine , who voted yes on maltreatment of ability and no on obstacle . No Republicans voted against Trump . Two Democrats , Jeff Van Drew of New Jersey , who is expected to switch parties soon , and Collin Peterson of Minnesota , voted with Republicans against both articles . One Democrat , Tulsi Gabbard of Hawaii , who is running for President of the United States , voted `` present '' on both articles . The test in the Republican-controlled Senate on whether to remove the President of the United States from agency will likely begin in early January . It is likely that Trump will be acquitted , because a two-thirds majority is required for conviction .

questions.question: Why did the House impeached Donald Trump for his NFL criticism ?

answers.answer: Trump was impeached last calendar month for maltreatment of ability and obstacle of Congress . Both charges relate to his efforts to pressure Ukraine to launch politically motivated investigations against his rivals ahead of the 2020 election while withholding vital military care and a White House merging that Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky desperately sought . On Wednesday , House Democrats laid out a broad yet detailed overview of the President of the United States 's dodge to pressure Ukraine into acceding to his personal demands while freezing security system aid and dangling a White House merging . On Thursday , House prosecutors discussed the constitutional grounds for impeaching Trump , and why his actions rise to the degree of impeachable behavior . They then turned their stress to Trump 's alleged maltreatment of ability .

questions.question: Why is there a COVID-19 vaccine but not an HIV vaccine ?

answers.answer: ARS-CoV-2 causes an acute disease , Covid-19 . It ’ s an contagion that most people will clear on their own , which means there ’ s a vanquishing immune reaction that a vaccine can aim to induce in ordering to protect people . That ’ s not true for something like HIV , a virus for which there is no vaccine despite decades of inquiry . HIV causes a chronic contagion and integrates itself into people ’ s genomes ; there ’ second no natural immune reaction that eliminates the virus that a vaccine can mimic . HIV also mutates much faster than coronaviruses do , meaning it ’ s more difficult to rally a last defense mechanism .

questions.question: Why is there no vaccine for a common coldness ?

answers.answer: Vaccines target a specific disease-causing pathogen , such as a virus . One of the difficulties in developing a vaccine for the common coldness is there are at least 200 different viruses that can cause cold symptoms , including adenoviruses , coronaviruses , parainfluenza , and rhinoviruses.1 Rhinoviruses are to blame for up to 50 % of all common colds.2 That seems like a big enough prey to focus on . But of these rhinoviruses , there are more than 150 strains circulating at any one time.3 Due to the limitations of current technologies , there is no manner for one vaccine to protect against all possible types and strains of the viruses that cause the common coldness .

To block this viral fastening to target cells , antibodies that target the viral open proteins specifically are secreted , which bind and neutralize the viruses , weakening their infective ability . However , in some viruses , the dressing of specific antibodies to viral open proteins can promote viral invasion into certain types of cellular telephone instead , and enhance viral contagion . This consequence is called antibody-dependent enhancement ( ADE ) ( see Glossary ) ( Taylor et al. , 2015 ) . ADE happens in two main cases : ( 1 ) when viral-specific antibody promotes viral introduction into horde monocytes/macrophages and granulocytes , and ( 2 ) when it enhances viral contagion in cells via interplay with the Fc sense organ ( FcR ) and/or complement sense organ . Enhancement of the fastening between viruses and prey cells play important function in most cases . ADE has been identified in over 40 kinds of virus . These viruses have several different antigenic epitopes , some of which induce neutralizing antibodies , while some induce enhanced antibodies . Conventional vaccine has shown a weak hindrance and therapeutic consequence on these viruses ( Wang et al. , 2016 ) , and in some cases has also been shown to increase the susceptibility of those who are vaccinated .

questions.question: What is Kenya ’ s last mile connectivity program ?

answers.answer: In 2015 , the politics announced the Last Mile Connectivity Program to improve entree to electricity in slums and rural areas in Kenya where connectivity is poor and aims to help achieve universal entree by 2020 . The “ last mile ” in Phase I of the Program referred to the final association to unserved households living within 600 metres of an existing transformer . In later phases , this was expanded to also include new transformers and the propagation of the low-voltage net . People who do not have entree to electricity are unable to achieve the same criterion of life as the households that do , and they have limited entree to economic opportunities .

questions.question: How many customers in Kenya were connected to electricity under the last mile connectivity program at the clock time the title was made in November 2020 ?

answers.answer: March 2017 : Kenya Power has confirmed that 5.9 million customers have been connected to the power system to go steady through ongoing government-led national electrification programmes .

In working towards achieving universal entree to electricity , the Company continued to implement the Last Mile connectivity and Transformer Densification projects supported by the Government GoK and other growth partners . During the 2018/19 class , a sum of 197,971 customers were connected under the Last Mile undertaking and 466 new single-phase distribution transformers were installed along existing distribution lines under the Transformer Densification undertaking . This contributed to increase in the act of customers connected by 306,771 .
In FY 19/20 , 79,868 customers were connected .
